text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Huh, and then we, huh, ask men to participate and also getting vitamin C. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That’s the experimental part. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So when the numbers change, it’s consent forms. Patient: Yeah, yeah, put that right Doctor: So that’s your homework. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and then I will send Dr. G an email tomorrow and make sure he sees what I’m thinking,

text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.

text: Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic. Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
